comms_internal: Same as 38. An alternative is the EXT&3ala_BARA pattern, cf. “Mḥammad ʕal-ē ḥarāra” (the predicate is COP) [PN on-O.3M fever] ‘Muhammad has fever’. The original questionnaire sentence was hard to elicit as the relevant meaning is typically conveyed by a verbal derivation “tgarrəb”: “Aḥmad mgarrəb” [PN have_flu.PTCP.MS] ‘Ahmad has flu.’

back_translation_en: ‘Ahmad took a book from the shelf.’

sentence: Aḥmad gass əl-ḥāyeṭ w wassex id-u

back_translation_en: ‘Ahmad touched the wall and got his hand dirty.’

comms_internal: Same as 2.
CV
Same as 119.
Same as 97.

Same verb as in 65, different pattern. The verb agrees with the Y argument (was checked with a noun like ‘money’, cf. “Sẓalat maʕ-ā šwayy-ət maṣāri” [remain.PF.3F with-O.3M little-CSTR.F money] ‘He had a little bit of money left’). The X argument is expressed by an extraposed bare NP and then once again by an index on the preposition.

The second argument displays some properties of the direct object. For example, pronominal forms trigger object agreement, cf. “qamīs-ak hēk? lā qamīs-i ġēr-u” [shirt-POSS.2MS so no shirt-POSS.1SG other-O.3M] ‘Is your shirt like this? No, my shirt is different from it.’ The X-argument does not trigger agreement on the nominal predicate itself, but in the past tense it behaves as the regular subject in that it triggers agreement on the copula: “qumsān-i kānu ġer qumsān-ak” [shirt.PL-POSS.1SG be.PFV.3PL other shirt.PL-POSS.2MS] ‘My shirts were different from yours.’
Same verb as in 61, different pattern.

The X-argument is encoded by a fronted NP and then indexed on the non-verbal predicate. It does not trigger agreement on the copula, cf. “kān bədd-i” [be.PFV.3M want-POSS.1SG] ‘I wanted’. The Y-argument, if pronominal, is indexed on the predicate as the regular DO, cf. “Mḥammad bədd-u-yā” [PN want-POSS.3M-O.3SG] ‘Mhammad wants it.’
Same adjective as in 115, different pattern.
